ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I developed my reading and writing skills
creative non-fiction writing - experience essay, location essay, cultural thing essay, profile essay

Your writing will improve dramatically when you take ENGL 120. Seriously, every person at Yale should take this class. Not only will you become a better writer, you'll learn how to think critically about the things you read. You'll also learn to appreciate the craft of writing. Over the course of the semester, you'll learn to write about yourself and others in ways that are evocative, vivid, and exciting. This class is spectacular.
I learned about writing non-fiction essays in several different topics, as well as read great examples of non-fiction essays
I learned how to more closely scrutinize my writing to improve it and how to effectively draft creative papers.
I learned how to write creative nonfiction essays.
I learned how to write nonfiction essays with an effective public point.
I improved my close reading skills and learned how to write engaging creative non-fiction essays by studying great authors.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Sometimes hard to speak during class with zoom but overall nice

strengths - instructor very open to student feedback, provided detailed essay feedback that helped me greatly improve creative writing skills
weaknesses - reading assignment time commitment varied for each class meeting - while this is unavoidable to some extent, some nights felt like they had a lot more reading/pages assigned than others

Strengths: Prof. Deli is fantastic! If you can, take her section! Classes are so engaging and you will learn so much during each class. The readings, while they can be somewhat laborious, are generally helpful in understanding what good writing is. The essay prompts are fun, and they all build upon each other. Workshop can seem stressful, but it's incredibly helpful when writing your final draft. The feedback you receive on each draft from Prof. Deli is detailed and helpful. She is willing to work with you to make your essays the best they can be. The pacing isn't terrible either. As long as you don't procrastinate until the night before the due date, the essays are fun to write. 

Weaknesses: none that I can think of.
This course is great in that the workshops and professor feedback really improve your writing substantially!
The workshopping is very helpful and I thought the interesting readings were also a strength.
Not enough time between essays

Strengths: great syllabus, interesting discussions, and a positive space (which was especially conducive for in-class workshops). Any weaknesses (disconnect and slower discussions) were because of the virtual format of the class.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Not much

This was definitely the course that most successfully transitioned to the online format. Seminars were so engaging that it was easy to forget we were on Zoom. The Canvas website was well-organized and heavily used.
I think that the virtual discussion sessions worked well, especially with the good use of breakout rooms.
Breakout rooms were a success!

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes
yes - although it was a good amount of work the course was worth it and I took away some useful writing skills and techniques

Absolutely. I honestly believe it should be a requirement to graduate. It will transform the way you view your writing, and the way you interact with writing in your daily life. This class is a gem, and Prof. Deli is one of the best professors I've interacted with. This should definitely be on your course schedule!
Yes!! The essays we read are great and workshop days are really insightful for improving your own writing.
I would recommend this course if you want to improve your creative writing and general prose skills.
Yes, the writing was very challenging for me, but I greatly improved in my writing abilities so I would recommend it.
Yes

Yes, yes, yes! At the end of the day this is a creative non-fiction course and you will absolutely love the break from academic writing. This does not mean your writing will not improve. It will. You will receive great feedback from Prof. Deli and your classmates, and you will draw inspiration from the amazing authors you read. The syllabus is great!

Yes!! The class is really great, and Maggie is so kind and so energetic, and she brought lots of life, even to a zoom room. It's a challenging class because there are lots of papers with rough and final drafts and a meeting with the professor between each, but it's really worthwhile because the feedback and revision process is what really makes someone a better writer. Every ENGL 120 professor chooses different essays to read, but I really liked Maggie's selection (especially when comparing to friends in other sections) because she really tries to incorporate a lot of different topics and authors.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: None other
This course consisted of virtual discussions, though one outdoor hybrid in-person/virtual class was attempted towards the end of the semester.
N/A
Had one hybrid class that was half in-person (for people on campus) and half virtual.
